sec.title: Synthesis

boxed-text.p: Reviewing Editor: Liset Menendez de la Prida, Instituto Cajal CSIC

Decisions are customarily a result of the Reviewing Editor and the peer reviewers coming together and discussing their recommendations until a consensus is reached. When revisions are invited, a fact-based synthesis statement explaining their decision and outlining what is needed to prepare a revision will be listed below. The following reviewer(s) agreed to reveal their identity: Niraj Desai.

sec.p: Your ms was reviewed by two independent neuroscientists and myself. We also consulted with a NASA expert. During the consultation there was some discussion regarding some major methodological issues and reviewers disagree on whether we should reject or not the paper at this point given the need for substantial revision requiring more than two moths.

However, we all agree your data is unique and that we should let you the chance to consider all these concerns. Thus, we decided to give you the chance of resubmitting a revised version. I should stress however, the need for a major and thorough revision. Your paper will be reviewed again and I will then look for a consensus recommendation.
Here is a synthesis of the reviewers' assessment. Given the relevance, I copy the NASA expert's comments at the end.
Major comments:

1- Potential confounding effects of radiation not accounted for (visual impairment and other physiological effects) to explain behavioural effects (see Ramos et al 2019 Experimental Eye Research; doi.org/10.1016/j.exer.2019.01.019). Several behavioral tasks in which radiation leads to functional deficits seem to involve visual discrimination. PLease, address this properly.

2- Additional confirmatory analysis are required to validate changes of intrinsic excitability and synaptic responses. First, change in resting potential seems a bit odd because there are no (significant) changes in input resistance or sag, which suggests there were no changes in leak, H, or GIRK currents. We are thus unclear on what may produce the resting potential change? (The rheobase effect could simply reflect the resting potential one.) The authors might address this question by analyzing intrinsic excitability more thoroughly than they do - for example, by measuring f-I curves, threshold potential, spike height, afterhyperpolarization, spike frequency adaptation. The current steps ranged between -200 pA and +750 pA, and yet the manuscript reports rather little about the responses to them. Second, intrinsic excitability measurements were done without blocking synaptic currents. This is not ideal - because, for example, a hyperpolarized resting potential could be the result of a decrease in excitatory background rather than a change in intrinsic channels. The confound is unlikely to be a major one in this case because the synaptic background (Fig. 1F) looks rather low. Even so, the authors should demonstrate that this is true for their recording conditions by recording intrinsic excitability before and after washing in synaptic blockers. This could be done simply with tissue from control animals.

3- Pseudoreplication issues. Patch clamp data of Figure 1 are derived, for each group, from 27 recordings taken from 7-8 animals. Each recording is treated as an independent observation in the analysis, but this treatment might not be valid. Recordings from a given animal might be correlated with other recordings from that same animal. The issue, called “pseudoreplication” (Lazic, BMC Neuroscience, 2010), has received a lot of attention in neuroscience recently. The authors should try to reanalyze those data “by animal” rather than “by recording.”

4- Additional analysis of behavioral experiments. The battery of behavioral tests is mostly well explained (if only by referring to conventional methods, previously described). One test on which I would like more detail is freezing. I am familiar with FreezeFrame. Its “automated” software includes some choices about how to block time and set a freezing criterion. What choices did the authors make?

5- Concerns regarding sEPSC decay. Whole cell voltage clamp on neurons with dendrites can be tricky, especially when one is trying to characterize a current from a distal site. What criteria did the authors use to determine that the synaptic currents they measured were well clamped? A rise time cutoff? A threshold? A stringent series resistance criterion and/or steps to minimize series resistance filtering? One thing I would recommend is to measure charge (by integrating each current). Charge is less sensitive to the effects of cable filtering.
6- The ms lacks many methodological details and should be thoroughly revised. Here is a list of concerns:
a) What series resistance, resting potential, and input resistance cutoffs did they use to determine whether a given recording should be included in their data set?
b) Did they balance the bridge and use pipette capacitance compensation when recording in current clamp?
c) What holding potential did they use in voltage clamp?

d) The authors are confident that the EPSCs are indeed excitatory because why? The GABA reversal was negative relative to holding? e) In the mPFC LTP experiments, did they do anything to block inhibition? In neocortex, that tends to be a big problem when stimulating extracellularly.
f) The extrapolation to NNH is not sufficiently justified and the cited paper does not include estimation of NNH
g) There is an abusse of abbreviation of brain regions and behavioral tests. Expanding these in the results would improve readability.
Some minor comments:

7- In one or two places, the authors report results to an unneecesary level of precision (control animals spent “80.899 +/- 2.465” percent of their time in the light area). In the text, the freezing responses are referred to as pure numbers rather than as percentages.
8- In figure 1 use sEPSC instead of EPSC for clarity
9- 449-453 and 475-483 are more appropriate in the discussion.
10- Figures 3A and 3B are incorrectly referenced in the results.
11- Relating the findings to radiation exposure during cancer radiotherapy could expand the relevance of the study
Finally. Here are commenst by the NASA expert. Please, address all of them carefully.
- Title should have neutrons in it - to differentiate from more harmful GCR particles (Galactic cosmic rays).
- Throughout the manuscript (significance etc) they talk about space radiation - but I feel that they need to be very specific -

- The real issue is likely due to secondary neutrons that interact with other particles - such as the space craft etc. Which they acknowledge - it is not clear if they are trying to model ambient neutrons in space or those from interactions with shielding (which are likely more important).
- I could not find much info on the current neutron rate/dose in space (neutrons decay in 10min) but in the Nelson 2016 paper they posit about 20-30mGy dose over three years.
- Paper is important as it is one of the first to do long-term exposures.

- The KDE is a smoothing function (estimate probability distribution of a random variable) and based on the results don't tell us how they fit the data - they simply grab the top 95% - but sort of poor rationale at least for me - They make some strong assertions based on the KDE - so they need to model this a bit better - details like the bandwidth that they used... there is an optimal (ie silvermans ) choice. KDE is not good for uniformally distributed data either.
- Ephsyio data looks good, but in some instances the resultant significance appears comes to come from a few animals in each that seem to drive the significance.

Overall interesting and important for space travel, but again neutrons are not overly important relative to heavy ions; I think if you decide to keep this manuscript, I would force them to be very specific on which types of neutrons they are modeling and that it is distinct from other GCR particles.

sec.title: Author Response
sec.p: We appreciate the opportunity to respond to the critiques, and we have also taken the liberty to include 95% confidence intervals for all our data sets in the main manuscript, thereby increasing the statistical visibility of our data sets. Below is a point-by-point response to the reviewers' comments:
Major comments:

1- Potential confounding effects of radiation not accounted for (visual impairment and other physiological effects) to explain behavioral effects (see Ramos et al 2019 Experimental Eye Research; doi.org/10.1016/j.exer.2019.01.019). Several behavioral tasks in which radiation leads to functional deficits seem to involve visual discrimination. Please, address this properly.

This is a good point but under the current context of our studies is simply not a concern. The reference quoted refers to the control of ocular tumor in the clinic through brachytherapy techniques or external beam radiation. The most common form of radiation therapy to treat ocular tumors is brachytherapy which brings the radiation source close to the cancerous tissue. Routine absorbed doses to the eye range from 70 -100 Gy and can lead to vision impairments within 6 months to 3 years following treatment. The critical feature here is that the radiation dose is 400 times higher than what was used in this study and our animals exhibited no signs of ocular complications whatsoever. Furthermore, in our behavioral tests, control and irradiated animals exhibited similar exploration to the objects during spontaneous exploration tasks indicating functional vision. For example, total exploration for both objects on the NOR task was 41{plus minus}3.8s (control) and 40{plus minus}2.6s (irradiated) and for the OiP task it was 80{plus minus}6.9s (control) and 71{plus minus}5.6s (irradiated). Neither was statistically different.

2- Additional confirmatory analysis are required to validate changes of intrinsic excitability and synaptic responses. First, change in resting potential seems a bit odd because there are no (significant) changes in input resistance or sag, which suggests there were no changes in leak, H, or GIRK currents. We are thus unclear on what may produce the resting potential change? (The rheobase effect could simply reflect the resting potential one.) The authors might address this question by analyzing intrinsic excitability more thoroughly than they do - for example, by measuring f-I curves, threshold potential, spike height, after hyperpolarization, spike frequency adaptation. The current steps ranged between -200 pA and +750 pA, and yet the manuscript reports rather little about the responses to them. Second, intrinsic excitability measurements were done without blocking synaptic currents. This is not ideal - because, for example, a hyperpolarized resting potential could be the result of a decrease in excitatory background rather than a change in intrinsic channels. The confound is unlikely to be a major one in this case because the synaptic background (Fig. 1F) looks rather low. Even so, the authors should demonstrate that this is true for their recording conditions by recording intrinsic excitability before and after washing in synaptic blockers. This could be done simply with tissue from control animals.

We agree that important details of intrinsic responses were previously excluded and we have now expanded the analysis we include. Based on the estimation statistics we have added to the manuscript, the 12.0 MΩ decrease in input resistance of irradiated mice qualifies as a small effect based on a Cohen's d of -0.43. However, we acknowledge that this result is not significant based on traditional statistical methods. Determining how to deal with such discrepancies will be important as neuroscientists seek to move beyond statistics relying on the binary verdicts of P-values.

With the F-I curve we now include, we show that neutron-irradiated neurons are less excitable across the range of current injections we performed. In a further analysis of the F-I responses performed only in a subset of neurons with equivalent resting membrane potentials, we still observe attenuated responses in irradiated neurons. However, we believe that the full dataset better represents the underlying biological finding that neutron irradiation decreases the excitability of CA1 pyramidal neurons. We have also added additional analysis of the AP thresholds, heights, widths and afterhyperpolarization, although we observe no significant changes in any of these measures (although the Cohen's d for the decrease in afterhyperpolarization following irradiation indicates a small effect).

We appreciate your suggestion of recording intrinsic excitability in the presence of synaptic signaling blockers to preclude any influence of synaptic currents on the intrinsic properties. However, as you point out, background synaptic activity appears to be relatively sparse in both of our treatment groups, making it unlikely to exert much of an impact on the intrinsic properties we measured. The control mice in the current experiments spent six months housed at Colorado State University under the equivalent conditions to the neutron irradiated mice before being shipped to Stanford University and aged an additional six months. Due to the complications of producing a comparable set of control mice for experiments looking into the impact of adding synaptic blockers on synaptic activity, we were unable to perform additional experiments. Nevertheless, we now note in our manuscript that decreases in the sEPSC frequency of neutron-irradiated mice could be correlated with the hyperpolarized resting membrane potential we observed.

3- Pseudoreplication issues. Patch clamp data of Figure 1 are derived, for each group, from 27 recordings taken from 7-8 animals. Each recording is treated as an independent observation in the analysis, but this treatment might not be valid. Recordings from a given animal might be correlated with other recordings from that same animal. The issue, called “pseudoreplication” (Lazic, BMC Neuroscience, 2010), has received a lot of attention in neuroscience recently. The authors should try to reanalyze those data “by animal” rather than “by recording.”

As you state above, the issue of pseudoreplication, or nested datasets, is definitely gaining attention among electrophysiologists. However, many in the field remain uncertain about how to update their statistical best practices while accounting for the technical constraints of performing slice electrophysiology experiments.

One emerging solution is to analyze datasets using mixed linear model regression analysis (also referred to as multilevel model analysis), where both the degree of within cluster and between cluster variability is accounted for (see Aarts et al., Nat Neurosci, 2014). We have now updated all significance testing between treatment groups in our whole cell electrophysiology experiments to a mixed linear model regression analysis. Furthermore, in line with emerging statistical guidelines at eNeuro, we have additionally included an estimation statistics-based calculation of the effect sizes observed between our treatment groups. We believe that through these two measures we address the concerns related to pseudoreplication without losing the transparency associated with presenting the responses of individual neurons.

4- Additional analysis of behavioral experiments. The battery of behavioral tests is mostly well explained (if only by referring to conventional methods, previously described). One test on which I would like more detail is freezing. I am familiar with FreezeFrame. Its “automated” software includes some choices about how to block time and set a freezing criterion. What choices did the authors make?

The trial viewer function in the FreezeFrame 4 software was used to determine the percentage-based freezing of animals. An investigator blinded to the experimental groups set the motion index threshold representing immobility for each animals individually, based on identifying a trough separating peaks of low values during immobility and higher values associated with motion. The freeze threshold was set between 10 to 16 (0 cGy: 10.51{plus minus}1.86, 18 cGy: 16.1{plus minus}0.94) for these experiments. Freezing behavior was defined as continuous bouts of 1 second or more of immobility. The percentage of time spent freezing during the tone was then calculated for the conditioning, extinction training and the extinction test phases.

5- Concerns regarding sEPSC decay. Whole cell voltage clamp on neurons with dendrites can be tricky, especially when one is trying to characterize a current from a distal site. What criteria did the authors use to determine that the synaptic currents they measured were well clamped? A rise time cutoff? A threshold? A stringent series resistance criterion and/or steps to minimize series resistance filtering? One thing I would recommend is to measure charge (by integrating each current). Charge is less sensitive to the effects of cable filtering.

We have further clarified the criteria used to characterize synaptic currents. sEPSCs detected in Clampfit were screened to only include events with a rise time of <7.5 ms, a peak amplitude of >3 pA, a charge transfer of >25 pC and recordings were excluded where the series resistance increased by >20% of baseline. As suggested, we have replaced our calculation of sEPSC decay times with a measure of the charge transfer during each sEPSC.
6- The ms lacks many methodological details and should be thoroughly revised. Here is a list of concerns:
a) What series resistance, resting potential, and input resistance cutoffs did they use to determine whether a given recording should be included in their data set?
Thank you for pointing out this oversight. We have now included information on these exclusion parameters in our methods section.
b) Did they balance the bridge and use pipette capacitance compensation when recording in current clamp?

Pipette capacitance compensation was performed for all recordings. However, we did not balance the bridge in the current set of experiments. The majority of electrodes used had a low resistance of 2.5-3.5 MΩ (with an overall range of 2.5-5 MΩ), thereby minimizing any introduced error in recorded voltages. Under the recording conditions utilized in these experiments we have noticed only minimal differences between recordings when we did or did not include a bridge balance adjustment. Furthermore, having an unbalanced bridge has a limited effect on the current injections received by recorded neuron, thus it has minimal impact on either the rheobase current of F-I changes we observe. We do recognize that it is important to consider the potential errors that could be introduced by an unbalanced bridge in recordings with elevated electrode resistances.
c) What holding potential did they use in voltage clamp?
The holding potential of -65 mV during voltage clamp recordings has been further clarified in the methods section and added to the results section (and the corresponding figure legend).
d) The authors are confident that the EPSCs are indeed excitatory because why? The GABA reversal was negative relative to holding?

To measure putative EPSCs, neurons were voltage clamped at -65 mV, which is depolarized relative to the expected EGABA of CA1 pyramidal neurons (~-71 mV, see Dargaei et al., PNAS, 2018). During analysis, only inward currents were analyzed as sEPSCs. However, measuring the reversal potential of likely sEPSCs was beyond the scope of the current experiments, so we are unable to comment on whether EEPSC did indeed surpass the action potential threshold of the recorded neurons. Nevertheless, we believe it is reasonable to label these inward currents as sEPSCs.
e) In the mPFC LTP experiments, did they do anything to block inhibition? In neocortex, that tends to be a big problem when stimulating extracellularly.

Response: Picrotoxin (GABAA receptor blocker) was not included in the bath solution. On page 9, second paragraph within the Methods section of the paper we describe the care taken in positioning the electrodes within the mPFC and include a reference by Kirkwood and Bear, 1994, which demonstrates that theta burst-induced LTP can be achieved without the use of GABAA receptor blocker if the recording and stimulating electrodes are positioned in cortical layers III and IV, respectively.
f) The extrapolation to NNH is not sufficiently justified and the cited paper does not include estimation of NNH.

We thank the reviewer for pointing out the fact that the NNH was indeed not cited in the Jewell paper. We have substituted the details of the website-based algorithm we used to calculate the NNH. http://araw.mede.uic.edu/cgi-bin/nntcalc.pl.

We are unclear why the reviewer thinks that the extrapolation to NNH was not sufficiently justified. The journal BMJ Best practice recommends such an approach for clinical trials to either calculate Numbers Need to Harm or Numbers Needed to Treat. The NNH is an important measure in evidence-based medicine and helps physicians decide whether it is prudent to proceed with a particular treatment which may expose the patient to harm while providing therapeutic benefits. Internationally renowned medical journals routinely publish articles related to clinical neuroscience that use NNH (e.g., DOI:https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(15)60715-2). Thus the validity of the technique is hard to dispute. This type of analysis has not been widely used in rodent studies, and while it is unusual, the design of our study, makes the application of this type of risk analysis appropriate.
g) There is an abuse of abbreviation of brain regions and behavioral tests. Expanding these in the results would improve readability.
We appreciate this concern and have expanded the abbreviations for the brain regions (mPFC, PRC). We have tried to minimize our use of abbreviations for the various cognitive tasks.
Some minor comments:

7- In one or two places, the authors report results to an unnecessary level of precision (control animals spent “80.899 +/- 2.465” percent of their time in the light area). In the text, the freezing responses are referred to as pure numbers rather than as percentages.
This has been fixed
8- In figure 1 use sEPSC instead of EPSC for clarity
Agreed, this change has been made.
9- 449-453 and 475-483 are more appropriate in the discussion.
These sections have been removed and incorporated into the discussion at your request (refer to pgs. 29-30).
10- Figures 3A and 3B are incorrectly referenced in the results.
Thank you - this has been fixed
11- Relating the findings to radiation exposure during cancer radiotherapy could expand the relevance of the study.

While we acknowledge this idea, we have specifically tried to avoid this since the radiation paradigm used here is distinctly different than any current radiotherapeutic protocol. The low dose rate of neutrons used here are not practical for the control of cancer growth and are not used in the clinic. Higher dose rate neutron sources are used in clinical practice but represent very different irradiation parameters from those described in this manuscript. As a consequence, we prefer to avoid any such clinical comparisons that could be mistakenly construed and lead to some unnecessary criticism from radiation oncologists.
Finally. Here are comments by the NASA expert. Please, address all of them carefully.
Title should have neutrons in it - to differentiate from more harmful GCR particles (Galactic cosmic rays).
Agreed
Throughout the manuscript (significance etc) they talk about space radiation - but I feel that they need to be very specific.
The manuscript has been checked carefully and is accurate regarding our usage of space radiation.

The real issue is likely due to secondary neutrons that interact with other particles - such as the space craft etc. Which they acknowledge - it is not clear if they are trying to model ambient neutrons in space or those from interactions with shielding (which are likely more important).

There can be no doubt that neutrons arising from GCR interactions with the spacecraft, body and planetary surface will contribute to the total dose that astronauts receive (see below). There are also other terrestrial based neutron sources that can deliver higher doses and dose rates of neutrons - typically used in the clinic for the control of malignancies. Importantly, our studies were not designed to model neutron exposures in space, but rather the low dose rates of ionizing radiation found in space. At present this can only be accomplished at the CSU facility implementing 252Cf fission neutrons, which deliver very low dose rates (1mGy/day) of neutrons and gamma rays, as stated in this manuscript. As a point of interest, the energy spectra of the fission neutrons are similar to those within the spacecraft after GCR interactions with 25 cm2 thick of aluminum shielding (see below).
I could not find much info on the current neutron rate/dose in space (neutrons decay in 10min) but in the Nelson 2016 paper they posit about 20-30mGy dose over three years.

The total dose expected over a 900 day mission to Mars (~500 days on the planet) has been estimated to be 40 cGy. The deep space dose rate is 1 mGy/day (all sources), which would be cut in half on the surface of Mars due to planetary shielding.
Paper is important as it is one of the first to do long-term exposures.
Thank you and this was in fact the principal driver for these studies.

The KDE is a smoothing function (estimate probability distribution of a random variable) and based on the results don't tell us how they fit the data - they simply grab the top 95% - but sort of poor rationale at least for me - They make some strong assertions based on the KDE - so they need to model this a bit better - details like the bandwidth that they used... there is an optimal (i.e. silvermans) choice. We appreciate your points, but I must re-emphasize that we are not trying to model neutron exposures in space. We can do space radiation simulations of the GCR much more accurately at Brookhaven National Lab, which is the source of 99.99% of the NASA radiation publications to date. Unfortunately, practical limitations prevent the use and operation of this facility for 6 continuous months. Our use of the neutron facility was designed specifically to simulate the prolonged low dose rate environment in space, with the added benefit that the integral neutron energy spectra from 252Cf fission neutrons is most realistic to the energy spectra of neutrons within the spacecraft calculated for a shielding thickness of 25 g/cm2 of aluminum. During a deep space mission to Mars, the total absorbed dose contribution from neutrons has been estimated to be ~10%, and would be derived from all GCR interactions liberating neutrons form the planet surface, all spacecraft components and the body of the astronaut. We have deliberately left the majority of these consideration out of the present manuscript, due to the target audience of this journal. Instead, we have decided to focus on the neurobiological impact of low dose rate radiation effects. If the reviewer and/or Editor think it necessary, we can easily incorporate additional radiation specific detail in the discussion.
